awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Engineering electrical synapses in a sensorimotor circuit
awd_abstract_narration:
As scientists work to regrow nerves and replace connections in damaged nerves, the ability to create and direct the connection, or synapse, between the nerve and next structure remains illusive. To date, pharmacological treatments and neural implants show promise in generating new synaptic connections; however, neither offers control over where synapses are established. Because a neural circuit's function relies a precise connection, a need exists to generate targeted synaptic connections as part of neural circuit repair. This project focuses on how to correctly pair neurons and differentiate these connections into functionally relevant synapses. Genetic engineering is already utilized to determine how neural circuits assemble and generate behavior.  Building on this basic neuroscience research, this work will repurpose genetic engineering tools to achieve a novel goal: engineering neural circuits. These results will develop tools to precisely manipulate neural connections and establish key principles for designing connections to have intended functional behavioral outcomes. This will lay the groundwork for genetic therapies to restore function to injured and diseased circuits thereby enhancing quality of life and reducing financial burden on our healthcare system. Undergraduate students will be integrated into the research team and a biomedical engineering learning series will be developed for juniors at a local high school that serves at risk and underrepresented minority students.  The goal of both will be to improve interest and retention in STEM, in particular in biomedical engineering.

Proteins that bind across a synapse, including gap junction subunits connexins, show promise for selective pairing and electrical synapse formation. When expressed ectopically, their homophilic interactions can generate novel connections in vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems. However, functional characterization of these putative electrical synapses remains limited. Here, the capacity for exogenous connexins (Cx36) to selectively engineer functional synapses will be investigated within an escape circuit of Drosophila melanogaster that contains the required genetic tractability to deliver genes to pre- and postsynaptic candidate neurons and neural accessibility to determine functional and behavioral consequences of engineering new connections. Synaptic function will be assessed through immunolabeling, optogenetics, in vivo whole-cell electrophysiology, and detailed behavioral analysis.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Electrical synapses are fundamental components of neural circuits.  They guide neural circuit assembly during development, they establish circuit computations and synchronization, and they have been implicated in both neuroprotective and neurodegenerative processes in diseased or injured neural circuits. The ability to control when and where electrical synapses are formed could profoundly impact human health, restoring neural circuit function or connectivity when circuits are damaged and reprograming neural circuits that are not functioning appropriately.  Here, in this Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project, our major goal was to generate and evaluate tools for engineering novel electrical synapses.  Electrical synapses are formed through the assembly of gap junction proteins. We built upon pivotal work performed in the 302-neuron nervous system of the worm C. elegans that demonstrated modified gap junction proteins from mice could be used to engineer electrical synapses in the worm.  As a logical next step in complexity, we attempted to utilize a similar strategy to engineer electrical synapses in the 200,000-neuron nervous system of the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster.  We generated novel genetic tools to express gap junction proteins between two neurons that are adjacent but not synaptically coupled.  We then took advantage of the genetic, anatomical, and functional accessibility of the fruit fly nervous system to evaluate these tools. We observed expression of gap junction proteins within fly neurons but were required to make additional modifications to the protein sequence to enhance their ability to appropriately traffic to the correct neuronal location and come in contact with gap junction proteins within an adjacent neuron.  As our tools for electrical synapses utilize vertebrate gap junction proteins that are conserved in humans, we believe our tools will have broad compatibility for wiring connectivity across invertebrate and vertebrate systems.  We envision this work as part of an initial endeavor to shape the relatively nascent but rapidly expanding field of neural circuit engineering. The tools developed in this project will expand into an even larger genetic toolkit that will be instrumental for neuroscience research to understand the function and regulation of electrical synapses, and in neural circuit engineering research to rewire or restore connections.

 

Additionally, as part of our broader impacts, we sought to fill a gap in neuroscience education for high school students.  While careers in neurotechnology are increasing, very few high school curriculums include neuroscience or neurotechnology exposure. We therefore developed and ran experiential-learning based workshops to provide high school students with hands on experience running neurotechnology experiments and analyzing the resulting data. This enables students to understand the process of neuroengineering research and consider opportunities for future careers in this field.  

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Catherine R Von Reyn
